column1: The documented history of Tallaght dates back to early Christendom in Ireland but the many archaeological sites in the area suggest the presence of Bronze Age and perhaps even earlier settlers in the area.
With the foundation of the monastery of Tallaght by St. Maelruain in 769 AD
column2: there is a more reliable record of the area's early history. The monastery was a centre of learning and piety
column3: particularly associated with the Céli Dé spiritual reform movement. It was such an important institution that it and the monastery at Finglas were known as the "two eyes of Ireland". St. Aengus
column5: was one of the most illustrious of the Céli Dé and devoted himself to the religious life. Wherever he went
column6: he was accompanied by a band of followers who distracted him from his devotions. He secretly travelled to the monastery at Tallaght where he was not known and enrolled as a lay brother. He remained unknown for many years until his identity was discovered by Maeilruain. They may have written the Martyrology of Tallaght together
column7: and St Aengus also wrote a calendar of saints known as the Félire Óengusso ("Martyrology of Aengus").  St. Maelruain died in 792 and was buried in Tallaght. The influence of the monastery continued after his death
column8: as can be judged by the fact that
column9: in 806
column10: the monks of Tallaght were able to prevent the holding of the Tailteann Games
column11: because of some infringement of their rights.In 811 the monastery was devastated by the Vikings but the destruction was not permanent and the annals of the monastery continued to be recorded for several following centuries. After the Anglo-Norman invasion in 1179
column12: Tallaght and its appurtenances were confirmed to the Diocese of Dublin and became the property of the Archbishop. The complete disappearance of every trace of what must have been an extensive and well organised monastic settlement can only be accounted for by the subsequent history of the place
column13: the erection and demolition of defensive walls and castles
column14: and the incessant warfare and destruction that lasted for hundreds of years.

column1: Throughout the greater part of the 13th century a state of comparative peace existed at Tallaght
column2: but subsequently the O'Byrnes and O'Tooles
column3: in what would become County Wicklow
column4: took offensive action and were joined by many of the Archbishop's tenants. As a result of this the land was not tilled
column5: the pastures were not stocked and the holdings were deserted. In 1310 the bailiffs of Tallaght got a royal grant to enclose the town. No trace of these defensive walls survive and there is no evidence of their exact location
column8: for the name of the Watergate Bridge which spans the Dodder on the Oldbawn Road. The continuation of such raids prompted the construction
column10: of Tallaght Castle
column11: and it was finished some time before 1349. Tallaght had become an important defensive site on the edge of the Pale. A century later the castle was reported to be in need of repair.The 17th and 18th centuries brought many changes to Tallaght. Many mills were built along the Dodder and this brought new prosperity to the broad area
column12: which saw the building of many houses.When Archbishop Hoadley replaced Archbishop King in 1729 he found the castle in ruins
column14: building himself a palace at a cost of £2
column15: 500. By 1821 the palace too had fallen into ruin and an Act of Parliament was passed which stated that it was unfit for habitation. The following year it was sold to Major Palmer
column17: who pulled the palace down and used the materials to build his mansion
column19: as well as a schoolhouse and several cottages. Parts of Tallaght House
column21: were incorporated into St Joseph's Retreat House

Attached to the castle was a long building which was used in the archbishop's time as a brewery and later as a granary and stables. When the Dominicans came
column23: it was converted into a chapel and was used as such until 1883
column24: when the new church dedicated to Fr Tom Burke (now the older part of the parish church) was built.The Dominicans came to Tallaght in 1855/6 and soon established a priory that was also a seminary for the formation of Dominicans in Ireland and on missions in Trinidad and Tobago
column28: and elsewhere. The cramped accommodation of Tallaght house was replaced by the austere priory in phases of 1864

column37: a Persian walnut of the eighteenth century.The old constabulary barracks on the main street was the scene of the engagement known as the 'Battle of Tallaght'
column38: which occurred during the Fenian Rising on 5 March 1867. On that night the Fenians moved out to assemble at the appointed place on Tallaght Hill. The large number of armed men alarmed the police in Tallaght who sent a warning to the nearest barracks. There were fourteen constables and a head constable under Sub-inspector Burke at Tallaght
column39: and they took up a position outside the barracks where they commanded the roads from both Greenhills and Templeogue. The first body of armed men came from Greenhills and
column40: when they came under police fire
column43: and were also dispersed. In 1936 a skeleton
column44: sword-bayonet and water bottle were found in a hollow tree stump near Terenure. It is thought that these were the remains of one of the Fenians who had taken refuge there after the Battle of Tallaght and either died of his wounds or was frozen to death.In 1888 the Dublin and Blessington Steam Tramway opened and it passed through Tallaght Village. This provided a new means of transporting goods and also brought day-trippers from the city.

column1: Shamrock Rovers F.C. are based in Tallaght
column2: and started playing in Tallaght Stadium in 2009. The club finished its first season in Tallaght as runners-up in the league. The club won their first League title in 2010. Rovers followed this up by winning the 2011 League of Ireland. Rovers hosted their first game in European competition in Tallaght in the second qualifying round of the 2010–11 UEFA Europa League against Bnei Yehuda from Israel
column3: with Rovers advancing 2-1 on aggregate. Rovers faced former Champions League and UEFA Cup winners Juventus
column4: Rovers were beaten 2-0 in Tallaght and 3-0 on aggregate. In 2011 the club played its first ever Champions League game and its first game in the highest level of European Cup Competition's since the 1987–88 European Cup
column5: beating Estonian Champions Flora Tallinn in the 2011–12 Champions League Second qualifying round. Rovers were then beaten 3-0 on aggregate in the next round by Danish Champions F.C. Copenhagen but advanced to the 2011-12 Europa League Play-off round. There they were drawn against Serbian Champions FK Partizan
column6: whom they defeated 3-2 on aggregate (2-1 on the night after extra time) to reach the group stages of the Europa League. This marked a famous victory for Irish football
column7: as it is the first time an Irish club has reached the group stages of a major European competition. Rovers also won the All Ireland Setanta Sports Cup in 2011. Rovers wrapped up a second league title in a row on 25 October 2011.
